R, Stats, and Open Science

A Linear Mixed Effect Model in the Wild

Joshua Wilson Black

Te Kāhui Roro Reo | New Zealand Institute of Language, Brain and Behaviour
Te Whare Wānanga o Waitaha | University of Canterbury

Last time

  • What is a mixed effects model?
  • Adding random effects to a linear model:
    • Use of lme4 and the lmer() function
    • Random intercepts ((1|group))
    • Random slopes ((0+variable|group))
    • Random intercepts and slopes (e.g. (1 + variable|group))
  • Use of model comparison
  • Some rules of thumb.

This time

  • A complex real life example.
    • incl. extracting random effects.
  • Generating plottable predictions from models.
  • Think about extensions

Real life example

Change in usage factors

  • Our models with data from (Sóskuthy and Hay 2017) look at the relationship between usage factors and word duration.
  • But what about change in usage factors.
    • e.g.: if a word becomes more frequent does it also become shorter?
    • e.g.: if a word is more frequently utterance final, does it become shorter everywhere?
  • Models in the paper address this question.

  • Change in frequency (\(x\) axis) leads to reduction in word duration (\(y\)).
  • Colours: baseline duration of word.
  • Points: raw data.
  • Dashed lines: predictions from alternative model.
  • Inserts: Duration reductions for word given reduction over time in all words.

Modelling strategies

  1. Two-stage model.
    1. Fit a model to control variation due to things we want to ignore,
    2. Extract random effects which capture variation of interest, fit a model to these.
  2. Single-stage model.
    • Fit a model with both control variables and variables of interest.
  • Lots of projects at NZILBB use something like (1).

The control model

control_full <- lmer(
  WordDuration ~ scale(YOB) +
    # Duration controls
    scale(dur.context) + 
    scale(seg.no) +
    scale(syll.no) +
    scale(syll.length.3) +
    # Prosodic controls
    final +
    initial +
    scale(final.prop.log) +
    # Predictability controls
    scale(prev_pred_wf_log) +
    scale(foll_pred_wf_log) +
    scale(prev_info_wf_avg) +
    scale(foll_info_wf_avg) +
    scale(unigram.google.gb) +
    # Repetition controls
    repeated.20 +
    # Word class control
    wclass +
    (1 + scale(YOB) | TargetOrthography) +
    (1 + scale(prev_info_wf_avg) + scale(foll_info_wf_avg) + 
       scale(final.prop.log) + scale(unigram.google.gb) || Speaker) +
    (1 | Corpus),
    data=big_dia,
    REML=TRUE # changed to fit quickly.
)

# save the model
write_rds(
  control_full,
  here('models', 'control.rds'),
  compress = "gz"
)

😨

🧐

Summary

summary(control_full)
Linear mixed model fit by REML ['lmerMod']
Formula: WordDuration ~ scale(YOB) + scale(dur.context) + scale(seg.no) +  
    scale(syll.no) + scale(syll.length.3) + final + initial +  
    scale(final.prop.log) + scale(prev_pred_wf_log) + scale(foll_pred_wf_log) +  
    scale(prev_info_wf_avg) + scale(foll_info_wf_avg) + scale(unigram.google.gb) +  
    repeated.20 + wclass + (1 + scale(YOB) | TargetOrthography) +  
    ((1 | Speaker) + (0 + scale(prev_info_wf_avg) | Speaker) +  
        (0 + scale(foll_info_wf_avg) | Speaker) + (0 + scale(final.prop.log) |  
        Speaker) + (0 + scale(unigram.google.gb) | Speaker)) +  
    (1 | Corpus)

Convergence

  • Fitting a model is a ‘minimisation’ problem.
  • Visual intuition: it’s walking around a mountainous landscape trying to find the lowest point.
  • ‘Convergence’ errors are failures to find a sufficiently stable place to stop.
  • Helpful link here
  • Sometimes it just needs longer (see ?update and link above.)

Predictions

  • Most straight forward approach: predict()
big_dia <- big_dia |> 
  mutate(
    pred_value = predict(control_full)
  )

Plot predictions

big_dia |> 
  ggplot(
    aes(
      x = unigram.google.gb,
      y = pred_value
    )
  ) +
  geom_jitter(alpha=0.1, width=0.8)

Plot predictions

Predictions (cont.)

  • It would be nice to be able to control the values we get predictions for.
  • Can use the newdata argument to predict()
  • Must specify all variables which went into the original model.
  • I find marginaleffects::predictions() with marginaleffects::datagrid() convenient.
  • Sets all non-specified variables to their mean value.
  • Can ignore scale() in formulae.
    • But I reckon you should scale before fitting models.

datagrid()

grid <- datagrid(
  unigram.google.gb = c(-15, -5),
  YOB = c(1910, 1980),
  model = control_full
)
grid |> knitr::kable()

predictions()

control_preds <- predictions(
  control_full,
  newdata = grid,
  re.form = NA
) 
control_preds |> 
  ggplot(
    aes(
      x = unigram.google.gb,
      y = estimate,
      ymin = conf.low,
      ymax = conf.high,
      colour = factor(YOB),
      group = factor(YOB)
    )
  ) +
  geom_ribbon(alpha = 0.2, colour=NA) +
  geom_line()

predictions()

Exercise 1

  • Download ‘control model’ (https://osf.io/q5wgh/)
  • Put it in a directory called models inside your project.
  • Load the model using read_rds() (make sure you have library(tidyverse)).
  • Find the variable names by looking at the model summary.
  • Generate and plot a prediction using datagrid() and predictions() (make sure you have library(marginaleffects))

Exercise 1 (cont.)

control_mod <- read_rds('models/control_full_ML.rds')
grid <- datagrid(
  final = c("TRUE", "FALSE"),
  YOB = c(1910, 1950, 1970),
  model = control_mod
)
preds <- predictions(
  model = control_mod,
  newdata = grid,
  re.form = NA
)
plot <- preds |> 
  ggplot(
    aes(
      x = factor(YOB),
      y = estimate,
      ymin = conf.low,
      ymax = conf.high,
      colour = final
    )
  ) +
  geom_errorbar(position=position_dodge(width=0.6)) +
  geom_point(position=position_dodge(width=0.6))
plot

Exercise 1 (cont.)

Extracting random effects

  • Sometimes random effects capture the variation we care about.
  • e.g. random effects for word include an intercept and slope.
    • intercept: some words just tend to be longer (or shorter) than other similar words.
    • slope: some words change duration more over time than others.
  • If we are interested in variation in the change in duration over time, the slopes capture what we are after.
    • i.e. we want the bit of the model corresponding to (1 + scale(YOB) | TargetOrthography).
  • We get at random effects using the ranef() function.

Using ranef

  • ranef() gives all the random effects.
  • Output is organised by grouping structure.
    • i.e., TargetOrthography, Speaker, Corpus.
  • Use $ to access the appropriate effects.
ranef(control_full)$TargetOrthography |> 
  knitr::kable() |> 
  scroll_box(width = "100%", height = "500px")

Exercise 2

  • Extract the by-speaker random effects.
    • ranef(control_full)$???
  • Make a plot using this data.

Using ranef() (Cont.)

# from analysis script on osf.io, slightly modified.
slopes_full <- data.frame(
  TargetOrthography=rownames(ranef(control_full)$TargetOrthography), 
  dur.change=ranef(control_full)$TargetOrthography[,2]
)
words_full <- unique(
  big_dia[
    ,
    c("TargetOrthography","foll_info_wf_avg","prev_info_wf_avg","foll.diff",
      "prev.diff","dur.context.avg","final.diff","unigram.google.gb",
      "unigram.diff.google.gb","final.prop.log")
  ]
)
words_full <- merge(words_full, slopes_full, by=c("TargetOrthography"))

🙈🙉🙊

## More detail provided in script on osf.io
# scaling to get: "change in s over 100 years"
words_full$dur.change <- words_full$dur.change*(100/sd(big_dia$YOB))

# Scale from original data set (to comapre with control model)
for (var in c("foll_info_wf_avg", "prev_info_wf_avg", "final.prop.log", 
              "foll.diff", "prev.diff", "final.diff", "unigram.google.gb", 
              "unigram.diff.google.gb", "dur.context.avg")) {
  words_full[,paste(var, ".s", sep="")] <- (
    (words_full[,var] - mean(as.numeric(big_dia[[var]]))) / 
      sd(as.numeric(big_dia[[var]]))
  )
}

The ‘treatment model’

treatment_model <- lm(
  dur.change ~ (foll_info_wf_avg.s + 
    prev_info_wf_avg.s + 
    final.prop.log.s +
    foll.diff.s + 
    prev.diff.s +
    final.diff.s + 
    unigram.google.gb.s +
    unigram.diff.google.gb.s)*dur.context.avg.s,
  data = words_full
)
summary(treatment_model)

The single-stage model

single_stage <- lmer(
  WordDuration ~ scale(YOB) +
    ## FIXED EFFECTS
    # other duration controls:
    scale(dur.context) + 
    scale(seg.no) +
    scale(syll.no) +
    scale(syll.length.3) +
    # prosodic controls:
    final +
    initial +
    scale(final.prop.log) +
    # predictability controls:
    scale(prev_pred_wf_log) +
    scale(foll_pred_wf_log) +
    scale(prev_info_wf_avg) +
    scale(foll_info_wf_avg) +
    scale(unigram.google.gb) +
    # repetition controls:
    repeated.20 +
    # wordclass controls:
    wclass +
    # INTERACTIONS
    scale(YOB):scale(dur.context) * (
      scale(prev_info_wf_avg) +
      scale(foll_info_wf_avg) +
      scale(final.prop.log) +
      scale(unigram.google.gb) +
      scale(foll.diff) +
      scale(prev.diff) +
      scale(final.diff) 
    ) +
    ## RANDOM EFFECTS
    (1 + scale(YOB) | TargetOrthography) +
    (1 | Speaker) +
    (1 | Corpus),
  data=big_dia,
  REML=TRUE
)

write_rds(
  single_stage,
  here('models', 'single_stage.rds'),
  compress = "gz"
)
#include: false
single_stage <- read_rds(here('models', 'single_stage.rds'))
summary(single_stage)
Linear mixed model fit by REML ['lmerMod']
Formula: WordDuration ~ scale(YOB) + scale(dur.context) + scale(seg.no) +  
    scale(syll.no) + scale(syll.length.3) + final + initial +  
    scale(final.prop.log) + scale(prev_pred_wf_log) + scale(foll_pred_wf_log) +  
    scale(prev_info_wf_avg) + scale(foll_info_wf_avg) + scale(unigram.google.gb) +  
    repeated.20 + wclass + scale(YOB):scale(dur.context) * (scale(prev_info_wf_avg) +  
    scale(foll_info_wf_avg) + scale(final.prop.log) + scale(unigram.google.gb) +  
    scale(foll.diff) + scale(prev.diff) + scale(final.diff)) +  
    (1 + scale(YOB) | TargetOrthography) + (1 | Speaker) + (1 |      Corpus)
   Data: big_dia

Lessons

Lessons

  • There’s lots of ways to model the same data!
  • The simple pieces we’ve looked at in previous sessions can be put together into very complex machines.
  • Plotting is your friend.
  • Important to say why you’re doing what you are doing.
    • …but don’t expect to have the single right answer.

Usage factors and duration in the QuakeBox

QuakeBox

  • QuakeBox 1 contains earthquake stories from around 700 people.
  • QuakeBox 2 contains re-recordings of around 100 speakers 8 years later.
  • Which of these patterns might be testable in the QuakeBox 1 (and/or 2)?

Summary

Summary

We have: - Looked at some very complicated models. - Generated and plotted model predictions. - Extracted random effects.

Next time: - Back to Open Science - How might we preregister an hypothesis about QB? - Time to learn some git.

Exercise 3 (if time)

  • Download the single-stage model: https://tinyurl.com/single-stage
  • Explore the model using the methods we have already seen.
  • Have a look at marginaleffects::comparisons()
  • Try generate a plot of change in duration by change in usage factors (hard!)
